items.author: UX Collective

items.title: About UX Collective
items.content:
# About

[UX Collective](https://uxdesign.cc/ "Go to UX Collective")

We believe designers are thinkers as much as they are makers. [https://linktr.ee/uxc](https://linktr.ee/uxc)

The UX Collective (ISSN: 2766-5267) is an independent design publication and blog built to help designers think more critically about their work. Curated stories on user experience (UX), visual, and product design. The polar bear is a reference to "Information Architecture for the Web and Beyond", one of the most famous books in UX.

Email: hello@uxdesign.cc

## EDITOR & Founder

[Fabricio Teixeira](https://uxdesign.cc/@fabriciot?source=collection_editor_card)

Designer, Editor at UX Collective + DOC + Sidebar.io [http://linkedin.com/in/fabricioteixeira](http://linkedin.com/in/fabricioteixeira)

## EDITOR & FOUNDER

[Caio Braga](https://uxdesign.cc/@caioab?source=collection_editor_card)

designer @ SurveyMonkey, editor @ UX Collective

items.author: UX Collective

items.title: Goodbye Siri and thanks for all the fish
items.content:
# Goodbye Siri and thanks for all the fish

Some weak mixed metaphors in the wake of the ripples of Appleâ€™s Liquid Glass

[![Neel Dozome](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/1*_EIggyvRmiJyz5tN9wXXvg.png)](https://dozome.medium.com/?source=post_page---byline--2319a4b54e9c---------------------------------------)

[Neel Dozome](https://dozome.medium.com/?source=post_page---byline--2319a4b54e9c---------------------------------------)

5 min read

Â·

3 days ago

Source

Tonnes of real and digital ink have been spilled after Appleâ€™s recently concluded Worldwide Developerâ€™s Conference (WWDC) 25. In short: Apple product launch generates much hype. Plus Ã§a change, plus câ€™est la mÃªme chose. The more things change, the more they remain the same. However, it is not, for once, a device that is catching all the attention â€” it is a â€œdesign languageâ€.

## UX is now the core differentiator of the Apple brand

So, Liquid Gasâ€¦er.. Glass..

Not to blow our own horns as UX people but, gosh this is humbling, I hadnâ€™t really prepared a speech butâ€¦ we are the Masters of Everything now! Iâ€™d like to thank my mother and father, my teachers, my wife and my agent, Siri, who always believed in meâ€¦

By placing smooth user journeys across its platforms at the heart of the brand, Apple has made explicit that user experience is the main differentiator from its competition. It kinda felt super trite to type that out. An exercise in the obvious.

A ruthlessly minimalistic form of Glassmorphism goes from trend to a core pillar of design. Only now it shimmers, shines and moves around like a seeâ€¦

[![UX Collective](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:96:96/1*mDhF9X4VO0rCrJvWFatyxg.png)](https://uxdesign.cc/?source=post_page---post_publication_info--2319a4b54e9c---------------------------------------)

[![UX Collective](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:128:128/1*mDhF9X4VO0rCrJvWFatyxg.png)](https://uxdesign.cc/?source=post_page---post_publication_info--2319a4b54e9c---------------------------------------)

[Published in UX Collective](https://uxdesign.cc/?source=post_page---post_publication_info--2319a4b54e9c---------------------------------------)

We believe designers are thinkers as much as they are makers. [https://linktr.ee/uxc](https://linktr.ee/uxc)

[![Neel Dozome](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:96:96/1*_EIggyvRmiJyz5tN9wXXvg.png)](https://dozome.medium.com/?source=post_page---post_author_info--2319a4b54e9c---------------------------------------)

[![Neel Dozome](https://miro.medium.com/?source=post_page---post_author_info--2319a4b54e9c---------------------------------------)
items.author: Neel Dozome

items.title: Why AI Might Be Fuelling Cognitive Bankruptcy
items.content:
AI promises amplified intelligence, but are we repeating old habits that bankrupt our thinking?

As artificial intelligence reshapes innovation, we discuss its impact on company culture and our future roles. Despite the advancements in technology, the same old organisational problems persist. Thatâ€™s what I want to discuss â€” and it begins with a message I received one evening.

Itâ€™s late, and my phone pings. A former work colleague has sent me a message asking for my thoughts on a _LinkedIn_ post. Itâ€™s a snapshot of a growing tension Iâ€™ve seen play out across the design industry again and again.

A snapshot of the growing tension in the design industry. [Learn more from the full LinkedIn post.](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/andybudd_design-is-rapidly-changing-more-super-activity-7341416067187011585-xA42?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop&rcm=ACoAAAR1XpkBQ_wesrUZsO-u1eYx82EnMSo1Mm0)

User-centred design champion _Andy Buddâ€™s_ post captures a troubling pattern: organisations replacing strategic thinking with tool-savvy execution. Meanwhile, recruitment specialist _Tom Scott_ highlights some symptoms: flatter design teams and a deeper focus on craft.

We see tools, teams, and technologies evolve constantly. Yet the friction keeps growing.

So, what was my response to the post?
items.author: Ian Batterbee

items.title: What the Law Says About Deceptive Design Patterns
items.content:
What the law says about deceptive design patterns. If we canâ€™t trust the industry to regulate itselfâ€¦ then what about the law?

How does the law protect users from tricky tech? Image from â€” [https://www.itpro.com/security/cyber-security/370253/new-emotet-socially-engineers-evade-detection](https://www.itpro.com/security/cyber-security/370253/new-emotet-socially-engineers-evade-detection)

[Deceptive patterns](https://www.deceptive.design/) are annoying, manipulative, unethical, but unfortunately legalâ€¦ or are they?

It turns out that, in recent years, governments around the world have become aware of the damaging nature of deceptive patterns â€” obstruction, nagging, sneaky pre-selections â€” and have addressed or even outright banned these practices.

## What are deceptive patterns?

Confirm shaming by saying â€œI prefer to pay full price,â€ as well as sneakily opting user into promotional emails. Image from â€” [https://www.ramotion.com/blog/dark-patterns-in-ux-design/](https://www.ramotion.com/blog/dark-patterns-in-ux-design/)

Sometimes referred to as â€œdark patterns,â€ deceptive design patterns are meant to be, you guessed it, deceptive. They are design choices that prompt the user to do something that benefits the company or product, rather than the user themself, essentially violating a userâ€™s autonomy. Deceptive patterns are meant to distort a userâ€™s decision making process with tricky UX.

They are deliberately misleading, confusing, and disappointingly common.

*   confirm shaming (ex. â€œNo thanks, I donâ€™t want to save 20% by signing up today.â€)
*   more prominence is givenâ€¦
items.author: Daley Wilhelm

items.title: The Solo Designer: One Seat, All the Hats
items.content:
The solo designer: One seat, all the hats
=========================================

It will teach you everything you need, if you survive.

[![Ed Orozco](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/1*hFR5cn0vxviknwzBmLN2_Q.jpeg)](https://edorozco.medium.com/?source=post_page---byline--a6ac5df0af32---------------------------------------)

[Ed Orozco](https://edorozco.medium.com/?source=post_page---byline--a6ac5df0af32---------------------------------------)

6 min read

Â·

Jun 23, 2025

Designers gush about how [FAANGs](https://medium.com/design-bootcamp/designing-at-faang-companies-f11fad376e2b) do design and thatâ€™s okay. FAANGs are responsible for a lot of design innovation.

However, centering the design discourse around how big tech designs warps the perception of young designers of how design should be done.

Being a solo designer is more common than you think
===================================================

In the US [99.9% of all businesses are small businesses](https://www.clearlypayments.com/blog/the-number-of-businesses-in-the-usa-and-statistics-for-2024/?utm_source=chatgpt.com#:~:text=99.9%25%20(31.7%20million)%20of%20all%20businesses%20are%20small%20businesses). Itâ€™s common for B2B startups to [hire a designer among their first 3 hires](https://www.lennysnewsletter.com/p/hiring-your-early-team-b2b) and, for some, itâ€™s the [19th or 20th hire](https://uxdesign.cc/213c307e78ec809fa529ceb0e4550cc5?pvs=25).

This means that the majority of (tech) companies in the US â€”and probably in the worldâ€” operate with just one designer. Yet when I speak with young designers, all they want to talk about is big tech design.

Iâ€™ve been a founding and solo designer 3x in my career and I love the role. So I want to do my part in helping solo designers share the spotlight and hopefully inspire more folks to take on the challenge.

Solo designer or founding designer?
===================================

Not all solo designers are founding designers and not all founding designers are part of the founding team. Founding designer is an unofficial title some startups give to their first design hire.

However, the designers Iâ€™ve spoken to prefer the title _solo designer_ so, for simplicity sake, thatâ€™s what I often use.

With that out of the way, letâ€™s talk about the job.

The most exciting role of your career
=====================================

Being a solo designer is an opportunity to do unique work and shape the design direction of a company. You get to develop a wide range of skills and, if youâ€™re lucky, youâ€™ll build a team to expand on your foundations.

However, if you donâ€™t have a lot of experience, or you prefer structured environments, being a solo designer will not be for you.

Differences with big tech
=========================

**Designers at big techs work on problems that someone else scoped out**. Solo designers at startups have a lot more ownership over identifying and scoping problems worth solving.

**They spend a large chunk of their day aligning stakeholders**. If you ask anyone working at a large organization what they spend most of their time on, youâ€™ll get the same answer: â€œmeetingsâ€.

Meetings can be important work, and they can be interesting, but itâ€™s not what many designers would call fun.

From the book â€œSprintâ€ by Jake Knapp and John Zeratski.

**Big orgs tend to pay much better than startups.** As a solo designers, a lot of your compensation will come in the form of _equity â€”_ you get to own a piece of the business_â€”_ and sure, until the startup hits product-market fit, equity is the equivalent of monopoly money. If that happens, oh boy youâ€™ll have a big pay day.

**You also get paid in reputation.** Itâ€™s hard to put a price on the prestige of working in big tech. Your parents sleep better a night if you work at a company that â€œexistsâ€. You tell people where you work and they go â€œoooh, niceâ€. But if your startup makes it, youâ€™ll become the coveted â€œ[zero-to-one designer](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/tomscottt_most-in-demand-roles-were-working-on-activity-7204752119885676547-S6Va?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop&rcm=ACoAAASzl4UBP_TJGJE1CD5xQypUzdKfLxx2My0)
â€ that recruiters drool over and that can open many doors of its own.

Solo designer isnâ€™t for the faint-hearted
=========================================

As a solo designer you often have to navigate challenges of influence, bandwidth, and scope of responsibility. All without having other design colleagues to bounce off ideas and getting support.

You are the director and the intern. Youâ€™ll spend Mondays working on high-level strategic research and Tuesdays creating social media assets. Youâ€™ll have to do a lot of stuff most designers look down upon, like making your bossâ€™s pitch deck â€œpopâ€.

The responsibilities that would otherwise be split among multiple designers with varying levels of experience, are now all yours. You have a lot of leverage, but it can be hard to cope, especially if youâ€™re early in your career.

It shouldnâ€™t be your first gig
==============================

As if building a design practice from scratch wasnâ€™t hard enough, doing it without a frame of reference is a recipe for insanity.

As a solo designer, you donâ€™t have a lot of time to research and figure out how to do things. Youâ€™ll do much better if youâ€™ve worked at other companies and you have an idea of where you want to take things.

However, if youâ€™re a speed-learning machine, it can be extremely satisfying to be able to read a book on a specific topic and applying what you learn the next day.

Be a pragmatic generalist
=========================

This is the ultimate individual contributor (IC) role and youâ€™ll thrive if you are a generalist who can see the big picture.

For example, building a comprehensive design system should be quite far down your list of priorities. There are tons of free [frameworks](https://ui.shadcn.com/) and [templates](https://www.framer.com/marketplace/templates/), that itâ€™d be foolish to burn your scarce time building and maintaining a custom library of styles and components.

With free resources like Tailwind, itâ€™s hard to justify spending days creating custom color scales from scratch.

Instead, you can focus on creating systems for iterating fast and [hitting product-market fit as quickly as possible](https://uxdesign.cc/designing-for-velocity-baafdc17aae3).

If your startup succeeds, and you get to build a team, youâ€™ll have plenty of time to worry about building a great system.

Solo doesnâ€™t have to mean alone
===============================

As a solo designer, you shouldnâ€™t think of yourself as a lone wolf. Instead, you should double-down on cross-disciplinary collaboration.

In the lack of dedicated teams for research and product management you are responsible for weaving the connective tissue between customers and stakeholders.

Meet people, ask for advice, learn from others.

Why would you want to be a solo designer?
=========================================

If youâ€™ve read this far, you now realize choosing between big tech and solo designer at a startup is not that straightforward. Hereâ€™s a quick summary to help you make up your mind.

Being a solo designer means:

*   Taking responsibility for the design practice of the company. Branding, visual language, research methods, and building design maturity.
*   Getting to decide on the design strategy of the startup. What are your marketâ€™s unmet needs and how your startup will tackle them.
*   The ultimate IC role. You get to experiment with tools and methods to figure out what works best for your startup.
*   Financial and reputational equity. You have skin in the game, not only financially, but also on the attribution of success or failure.

Conclusion
==========

Being a solo designer is not for everybody. But itâ€™s an opportunity for you to do unique work. It allows you to develop a wide range of skills and influence the design direction of your company.

It is especially interesting for mid-to-senior designers who want to work on many different product challenges, and who already have a sense of what good design practices look like.

Sure, it doesnâ€™t have the sex appeal of working at a big company, but Iâ€™d argue it can be a lot more
items.author: Ed Orozco

items.title: Broken rhetoric of AI, goodbye Siri, accessible type, beyond journey maps
items.content:
Weekly curated resources for designers â€” thinkers and makers.

[![Fabricio Teixeira](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/1*86azy9AQulxnSdnJdvctFQ.jpeg)](https://fabriciot.medium.com/?source=post_page---byline--f05379c587bc---------------------------------------)

[Fabricio Teixeira](https://fabriciot.medium.com/?source=post_page---byline--f05379c587bc---------------------------------------)

Sent as a[Newsletter](https://uxdesign.cc/newsletter?source=post_page---byline--f05379c587bc---------------------------------------)

Â·

3 min read

Â·

6 hours ago

[The broken rhetoric of AI](https://uxdesign.cc/the-broken-rhetoric-of-ai-f3a24165899d)
 **â†’**By

[Mike Schindler](https://medium.com/u/68d7d1cacbda?source=post_page---user_mention--f05379c587bc---------------------------------------)

â€œWeâ€™re about a year into the Great AI Divide, or whatever our history-keeping algorithms decide to call this moment, and even the most literate among us canâ€™t help falling into the same old rhetorical pitfalls â€” ones that seem to alienate more people than they invite into the conversation.â€

Editor picks
============

*   [**Why I wanted 2 weeks before writing about Liquid Glass**](https://uxdesign.cc/liquid-glass-fragile-ux-and-why-i-wanted-2-weeks-before-writing-about-it-5dccafb5c28f)
     **â†’**  
    Itâ€™s glossy. Itâ€™s boldâ€¦ and controversial.  
    By
    
    [Oleg Safranov](https://medium.com/u/24611c24f2e4?source=post_page---user_mention--f05379c587bc---------------------------------------)
    
*   [**What the law says about deceptive design patterns**](https://uxdesign.cc/what-the-law-says-about-deceptive-design-patterns-3fddc7b11586?sk=d9497d0eb391aef8056e2976a0b9f201)
     **â†’**  
    We canâ€™t trust the industry to regulate itself.  
    By
    
    [Daley Wilhelm](https://medium.com/u/8ab653ea27a6?source=post_page---user_mention--f05379c587bc---------------------------------------)
    
*   [**Goodbye Siri and thanks for all the fish**](https://uxdesign.cc/goodbye-siri-and-thanks-for-all-the-fish-2319a4b54e9c?sk=6bb796f3a2019f3deefa5db1738d7478)
     **â†’**  
    Some weak mixed metaphors.  
    By
    
    [Neel Dozome](https://medium.com/u/b5d031ec16c5?source=post_page---user_mention--f05379c587bc---------------------------------------)
    

_The UX Collective is an independent design publication that elevates unheard design voices and helps designers think more critically about their work._

[**Garden of Sleep: tracking the emotional distance between two bedtimes**](https://nightingaledvs.com/a-garden-of-sleep/?ref=sidebar)
 **â†’**

Make me think
=============

*   [**The AI lifestyle subsidy is going to end**](https://digitalseams.com/blog/the-ai-lifestyle-subsidy-is-going-to-end?ref=sidebar)
     **â†’**  
    â€œWhether youâ€™re enthusiastically generating or reluctantly dismissing another pop-up for a useless chatbot, right now is the best itâ€™s ever going to be. Oh, the technology is going to get better. But what about your experience as a user?â€
*   [**Quality is a trap**](https://ericwbailey.website/published/quality-is-a-trap/?ref=sidebar)
     **â†’**  
    â€œLike cicadas emerging from the ground, design industry conversations about quality seem to periodically erupt on social media. (â€¦) Itâ€™s still a foolâ€™s errand, however. Conversations around quality are non-starters, for a variety of reasons.â€
*   [**Career advice, or something like it**](https://brooker.co.za/blog/2025/06/20/career.html?ref=sidebar)
     **â†’**  
    â€œIf I could offer you a single piece of career advice, itâ€™s this: avoid negativity echo chambers. Every organization and industry has watering holes where the whiners hang out. The cynical. The jaded. These spots feel attractive. Everybody has something they can complain about, and complaining is fun. These places are inviting and inclusive: as long as youâ€™re whining, or complaining, or cynical, youâ€™re in. If youâ€™re positive, optimistic, or ambitious, youâ€™re out. Avoid these places.â€

Little gems this week
=====================

[**The solo designer: one seat, all the hats**](https://uxdesign.cc/the-solo-designer-one-seat-all-the-hats-a6ac5df0af32)
 **â†’**By

[Ed Orozco](https://medium.com/u/9373adfc5a12?source=post_page---user_mention--f05379c587bc---------------------------------------)

[**Your brain on ChatGPT â€” my notes on the study**](https://uxdesign.cc/your-brain-on-chatgpt-my-notes-on-the-study-6e612c6d92dd)
 **â†’**By

[Michael F. Buckley](https://medium.com/u/491633cab109?source=post_page---user_mention--f05379c587bc---------------------------------------)

[**Are we designing AI products all wrong?**](https://uxdesign.cc/are-we-designing-ai-products-all-wrong-d54d1005c92f?sk=8a891a30786e53a5cfbcb8eb82b5acb8)
 â†’  
By

[Hoang Nguyen](https://medium.com/u/61fc6383ba67?source=post_page---user_mention--f05379c587bc---------------------------------------)

Tools and resources
===================

*   [**Accessible typography**](https://uxdesign.cc/its-more-than-picking-a-pretty-font-10897b392940)
     **â†’**  
    Itâ€™s more than picking a pretty font.  
    By
    
    [Allie Paschal](https://medium.com/u/b2f44e1879c9?source=post_page---user_mention--f05379c587bc---------------------------------------)

    Designing for control in AI UX.  
    By

    7 brutally honest takeaways from working at startups.

items.title: The broken rhetoric of AI. A detox guide for designers navigatingâ€¦
items.content:
# The broken rhetoric of AI

_A detox guide for designers navigating todayâ€™s AI discourse_

![Mike Schindler](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/1*Oo3S32Y2BwsUKXKOLqucYA@2x.jpeg)

[Mike Schindler](https://medium.com/@mschindler?source=post_page---byline--f3a24165899d---------------------------------------)

9 min read

Â·

4 days ago

AI-generated image by Mike Schindler

We really have some shitty ways of talking about AI.

Weâ€™re about a year into the Great AI Divide, or whatever our history-keeping algorithms decide to call this moment, and even the most literate among us canâ€™t help falling into the same old rhetorical pitfalls â€” ones that seem to alienate more people than they invite into the conversation.

Weâ€™re losing ourselves to our worst instincts. Not because weâ€™re doomed, but because weâ€™re treating this moment like a game of hot takes and hustle. But right now is actually a rare and real opportunity for a smarter, more generous conversation â€” one that helps our design community navigate uncertainty with clarity, creativity, and a sense of shared agency.

Instead, weâ€™ve turned the discourse into a pissing contest.

Who can get the most engagement?

Who can rattle the most nerves?

Who can [split the room](https://www.jackboxgames.com/games/split-the-room) and put the most distance between the supposedly old â€œarchaicâ€ ways and the newer, more exciting, vibey ones?

In this process we never think to ask if abdicating our creative judgment almost completely to the Large Language Model gods is a good idea. Itâ€™s like weâ€™re a tribe of primitive Luddites offering up our drudgery in return for a magical oracle that only rewards the loudest acolytes.

Weâ€™re playing into our performative identities because weâ€™re afraid of being left out in the cold.

Meanwhile, weâ€™re forgetting the most important thing:

**There _are_ healthier ways to talk about all this.**

Not to conjure a rose-colored world from the early 2000â€™s, but it was almost the exact same landscape of uncertainty, excitement, and novelty way back then. But somehow our approach and our sense of community was totally different.

Maybe Limp Bizkit deserves more creditâ€¦ hmmâ€¦ (remembers the backwards red hat)â€¦ nah.

But I do remember because I was there. A lot of us were. And the evidence of the discourse taking a dangerous corner today is all around us.

**Healthy conversations donâ€™t make you feel gross.**

They donâ€™t leave you rattled, reactive, or self-doubting.

They donâ€™t flatten all of the nuance into an abstract point or pit us against each other in a weird flex-off.

They invite participation. They build. They move forward like a good improv scene â€” like a â€œyes, andâ€¦â€ that encourages more voices, more learning, and more possibility.

Every good designer knows that solving any complex problem means you have to _identify_ it first.

So thatâ€™s what this is. A simple ID exercise.

A catalog of our worst impulses â€” not to shame, but to offer better, healthier alternatives.

Iâ€™m certain that most of what weâ€™re doing is unconscious and unintended by good-hearted people. But thatâ€™s just the point, isnâ€™t it?

By surfacing the patterns in how we talk about AI â€” often with fear, status anxiety, and noise â€” Iâ€™m hoping we can grow past this weird liminal phase.

Not heaven. Not hell. Just a low-level echo chamber where every LinkedIn post feels simultaneously urgent, predictable, andâ€¦ exhausting.

So, what Iâ€™m proposing is a bit of a detox from our usual way of talking.

And Iâ€™m suggesting some healthy alternatives instead.

Designed by Mike Schindler (mschindler.com)

## âŒ FOMO

> _â€œEveryoneâ€™s ahead of me. I need to catch up or Iâ€™ll be obsolete.â€_

This is the dark hum of the current discourse. You see it between the lines of almost every AI post. The implication is simple. _If youâ€™re not prompt-engineering throughout your entire design process, youâ€™re already behind._

Simple fear of missing out.

Itâ€™s not just anxiety â€” itâ€™s a quiet arms race of self-erasure, where speed takes up all the oxygen in the room and thoughtful reflection somehow feels like a liability.

### ğŸŒ± A Healthier Way: Curiosity-Driven Learning

The truth is, [the cheese is _always_ moving](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Who_Moved_My_Cheese%3F).

Thatâ€™s the nature of knowledge work. Change isnâ€™t a moment â€” itâ€™s our constant state of being.

As [Peter Drucker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Drucker) famously warned:

> â€œThe greatest danger in times of turbulence is not the turbulence â€” it is to act with yesterdayâ€™s logic.â€

At the rate weâ€™re going, every year, every month, even every week is more complex than the last. The pace wonâ€™t slow down â€” but the way we show up to each day _can_.

So what if we saw this moment not as an exercise in sprint conditioning, but as an invitation to learn?

Leading with curiosity reframes the AI shift from _â€œWhat am I missing?â€_ to _â€œWhat can I explore that aligns with my values, my practice, and the people I serve?â€_

It puts the designer back in the loop â€” not as a bottleneck, but as a rational and strategic human-centered synthesizer.

Not optimizing just for speed, but for shared understanding.

## âŒ Gaslighting

> _â€œDesign is dead. AI has already replaced you. Stop trying.â€_

The velocity of change weâ€™re experiencing has created a kind of virtual chasm in our shared reality. Itâ€™s no wonder the discourse has taken on a theatrical tone â€” half prediction, half panic.

Enter [gaslighting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaslighting).

Thatâ€™s when the dread warriors, armed with half-baked provocations and usually a touch of _mansplaining_, sow doubt under the guise of thought leadership. Their goal isnâ€™t clarity or education â€” itâ€™s status.

If youâ€™ve started to question your own sanity, thatâ€™s an important clue and hereâ€™s what to tell yourself. Youâ€™re probably still grounded. The gaslighters just want you to think otherwise.

This isnâ€™t just annoying. Itâ€™s manipulative. Itâ€™s pervasive. And itâ€™s all too common in our professional and political atmospheres.

But hereâ€™s the thing. We donâ€™t have to accept their reality as our fate.

Even if only a fraction of what they say is true, the rest is still noise â€” and we have the right to filter for our own peace of mind.

### ğŸŒ± A Healthier Way: Critical Perspective

I go by a simple rule of thumb.

Your experience is not my experience.

Instead of questioning if every move we make relative to our peers or competitors is correct or not, why donâ€™t we just recognize each other as unique individuals, all in our respective places in work and in life?

Chances are the gaslighters live in a bubble filled with their own innate [Blue Velvet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Booth_(Blue_Velvet)) gas. Let them suck it all in while you stay sane.

## âŒ Clickbait

> _â€œAI will replace UX.â€ or â€œNo-code is the end of design.â€_

Weâ€™ve all seen the headlines. Weâ€™ve all clicked the links.

This daily apocalypse is a new kind of engagement economy. Letâ€™s call it **Hysteria-as-a-Service**. Crafted by people who are either too clever by half or too thoughtless by whole.

These proclamations donâ€™t predict the future â€” they provoke the present.

They divide us into two groups. The doomed and the destined. The washed and the winners.

Itâ€™s narrative bait for our most primitive instincts.

Shame on them for leading us with these clicks.

Click again, and shame on us â€” and Shamu for that matterâ€¦ (sorry, that was a shame spiral).

I get it. Weâ€™re visceral beings. We sat through eight seasons of _Game of Thrones_ because [the pilot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winter_Is_Coming) blew up everything we thought we knew about the rules of televisionâ€” and the rest of the show kept us locked in with intermittent sex, violence, and surprise beheadings.

The internet does the same thing, only without the sets or the CGI dragons. It thrives on the tease. But unlike Westeros, thereâ€™s rarely any payoff.

Every article promising _â€œThe Death of Design Is Coming Sooner Than You Thinkâ€_ or _â€œWhy Iâ€™m Leaving UX (and You Should Too)â€_ echoes in a sea of sameness. The volume is high, but the depth is shallow.

### ğŸŒ± A Healthier Way: Nuanced Storytelling

The alternative is simple, but not easy. We have to value substance over spectacle.

Instead of indulging our
items.author: Mike Schindler
